Text.content:
So far, the template JSP had some dynamic aspects in printing context information for the page currently requested.

The most important dynamic aspect of a website template is, of course, that editors can add new contents to a web page.

An area on a page where editors can add new contents is called a Container in OpenCms. A container is like a parking place. Even if empty, it takes up a certain amount of space. The space can be occupied by one ore more elements of different types. There are rules that cause not every element type may occupy a certain container. And there is a maximum limit of available element slots.

In the example below, the <cms:container> is named main. A template JSP may contain more than one container. The individual name should be unique within the whole template.

The container is of type element, which means that, for now, any element may occupy this container. The type name element is freely choosen.

The maxElements attribute restricts the size of the container to a maximum number of 30 elements.

Inside the container, there is a DIV representing the drop area, where editors can drag and drop new contents. Make sure that this DIV has a defined width and height, event if empty.
